source.name: Gapminder
source.additionalInfo: Gapminder dataset. Available online at http://www.gapminder.org/.

8670.name: GDP per capita in 1990 Int. GK$ (Maddison-Project 2013)
8670.description: GDP per capita in 1990 international Geary–Khamis dollars.
8670.datasetName: Historical GDP per capita – Maddison Project (2013)

source.name: Maddison-Project (2013)
source.dataPublisherSource: Bolt, J. and J. L. van Zanden (2014). The Maddison Project: collaborative research on historical national accounts. The Economic History Review, 67 (3): 627–651.
source.additionalInfo:
The source notes: The Maddison Project has launched an updated version of the original Maddison dataset in January 2013. The update incorporates much of the latest research in the field, and presents new estimates of economic growth in the world economic between AD 1 and 2010. The new estimates are presented and discussed in Bolt, J. and J. L. van Zanden (2014). The Maddison Project: collaborative research on historical national accounts. The Economic History Review, 67 (3): 627–651.

The original data, as provided by the source, does not include observations for Belgium 1835-45. Our series includes observations obtained from implied growth rates in the GDP series provided by Berthold Herrendorf, Richard Rogerson and Akos Valentinyi (2014) – “Growth and Structural Transformation” Handbook of Economic Growth Vol. 2B

42803.name: Share of industry in GDP at constant 2005 prices (GGDC)
42803.description: Estimates of value added by economic sector at constant 2005 national prices (expressed as share of total value added at constant 2005 national prices).
42803.datasetName: Historical employment and output by sector – OWID (2017)
42803.s_name: Our World In Data based on GGDC-10 (2015)

source.name: Our World In Data based on GGDC-10 (2015)
source.dataPublisherSource: Various sources. Check documentation for details.
source.additionalInfo: The only changes we applied to the GGDC 10-sector database were: (i) dropping observations for GDP shares in Peru 1950-1985 since these are reported as negative in the original; and (ii) dropping observations for GDP shares in the Netherlands 1949-1959, since these are comparable to the period after 1960, as suggested by a marked jump in levels in the original series.
